title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - History and Citizenship Education (2010)
subject: Social Sciences

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - History and Citizenship Education (2010)

FFA68A245F2D400BB6BCE15D63CAF8F4.description: Gives examples of actions taken by organizations to promote the recognition of civil rights and freedoms (e.g. denunciations, boycotts, publications)

DCD4097689A541F1BECEAC06A6136B12.description: Indicates actions that illustrate the exercise of fundamental rights (e.g. demonstrations, elections, petitions, open letters)

F6B0823D715943D09E6576098C5E4B2D.description: Names organizations that fight for civil rights and freedoms (e.g. Amnesty International, Human Rights Watch, SOS Racisme)

0FD8034972104067B8860DAC3C7BF562.description: Responsibilities of individual in the struggle for and recognition of civil rights and freedoms today

9DA4BBBDF8164557A17DCCC8D1996C85.description: Indicates gains made by populations that have fought against colonialism (e.g. independence of numerous states in Asia and Africa)

AB6783CA8C284630A2EBC383DF332713.description: Indicates reactions to the decolonization movement (e.g. repression, wars)

92DA237DC48A48E4802EC9BB7A880B2B.description: Indicates actions taken by those opposed to colonialism (e.g. boycotts, passive resistance, riots, wars)

AC7C2AD348DE4CDCAC4D855CC025624F.description: Names actors associated with decolonization (e.g. Gandhi, Senghor, United Nations)

812CAA7F98B048DCA78C82DB69D41A40.description: Indicates wrongs suffered by colonized populations (e.g. discrimination, segregation, lack of economic control, imposition of a foreign culture)

E71932D2E31F4ADA9240E6446D3BD4BE.description: States some of the principles in the Charter of the United Nations on which groups opposed to colonialism base themselves (e.g. principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples)

A3BB22E8A2964968ADFE3B15D42D4972.description: Indicates gains made by Blacks, particularly in the United States and South Africa (e.g. Civil Rights Act, Voting Rights Act, abolition of Apartheid) OR

AD2D17A48AED4440AA6F9E8C567D9CB3.description: Indicates reactions to movements for the recognition of freedoms and civil rights (e.g. repression, imprisonment)

B06F320FA19342D7BEA2034B9D4A2A8C.description: Indicates actions taken by citizens or states to fight against racism in the 20th century (e.g. passive resistance, demonstrations, riots)

3251048978844A29AC293666870BCBAE.description: Names figures associated with the struggle against racial segregation (e.g. Rosa Parks, Martin Luther King, Nelson Mandela)

B6112108F21643B28733BBD207B3411A.description: Indicates wrongs suffered by Blacks in the United States in the first half of the 20th century and in South Africa before the abolition of Apartheid (e.g. discrimination, segregation, denial of civil rights)

7AA75F68654740DDA25917B2C97D5E31.description: States some of the rights in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights on which anti-racism movements are based (e.g. principle that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights)

C46366DFEED043288D66832202CC667C.description: Indicates gains made by feminist movements in the West (e.g. right to vote, access to higher education) OR

303A420C2462424CB229BFC37AA0DF86.description: Indicates reactions to the feminist movement (e.g. repression, creation of associations opposed to the recognition of civil rights for women)

71B0E863235D49668F4C47ADBB28ED61.description: Indicates actions taken by feminists or women’s groups in the 20th century (e.g. demonstrations, publication of books and manifestos)

6634388F232F42B18B9F6F5A8CD70DE2.description: Names figures associated with the feminist movement (e.g. Simone de Beauvoir, Betty Friedan, suffragettes)

02F863FAD67E4431B1D443409C894048.description: States some of the rights in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights on which feminist movements are based (e.g. principle that there must be no discrimination based on sex in the application of rights)

6C1AC0E461814E0FB6D92720309E5409.description: States some of the rights in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights on which feminist movements are based (e.g. principle that there must be no discrimination based on sex in the application of rights)

D11E4EEF43F0401F9B028D49CBF6D820.description: Locates on a time line events related to the feminist movement (e.g. winning the right to vote in several countries; publication of The Second Sex, by Simone de Beauvoir; the founding of the National Organization for Women) OR Locates on a time line events related to the Black civil rights movement in the United States and South Africa (e.g. Martin Luther King’s speech at the Lincoln Memorial, Civil Rights Act, abolition of Apartheid) OR Locates on a time line events related to decolonization in Asia and Africa (e.g. independence of India and Pakistan; Bandung Conference; independence of Algeria)

4D890F4C80E247B8BE536CA6C06BDE37.description: Recognition of civil rights and freedoms and impact on societies of the winning of civil rights and freedoms

FA60D2090617499D8520DF781DE05256.description: Indicates current situations in which civil rights and freedoms are ignored (e.g. exploitation of children, sex trafficking, countries under dictatorship)

3102BB49C4F34ED5865E01423490FED6.description: Indicates situations in which governments may limit or suspend civil rights and freedoms (e.g. government decision in case of war, a crisis or a perceived threat to national security)

112CF936E675451B9C9F329BAC61C148.description: Lists civil rights and freedoms (e.g. the right to vote, the right to justice, equality before the law, freedom of expression, freedom of religion)

3FA6FF433DF24C2DAF971FECFBFB56CF.description: Civil rights and freedoms today: denial, struggle and recognition

A152DE044A694265996F68755F520DA5.description: Winning of civil rights and freedoms

B88A9C82523B47D69C3E45BB84EF2C62.description: Explains the social and economic relationships between former colonies and colonial powers (e.g. important ties remain as decolonized countries often trade with former mother countries; Europe receives an important influx of immigrants from its former colonies)

A161B212D0A0466EB89B50C698329243.description: States the purpose of the North American Free Trade Agreement: to promote trade between Canada, the United States and Mexico by limiting tariffs

CD533DB5699B4E209A2BB2277B364758.description: Names international economic associations (e.g. European Union, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries)

FCA75A5DF35145A78C9E5B1205274F84.description: Names political organizations made up of former colonies (e.g. Organisation internationale de la francophonie, the Commonwealth of Nations)

B013C35F29454B79A1F03591A5D9C288.description: Political, economic and cultural relationships among societies today

B71C040FD22C4916BE28B720FB4DF465.description: Indicates how colonized populations reacted to European dominance (e.g. some Africans profited from their collaboration with the colonizer; some colonized populations organized uprisings and rebellions)

DB8FE56DE8F04DFCB9AF0B5C04F3B438.description: Indicates the role of education in the transformation of African cultures (e.g. the language of education was often the language of the colonizer; teaching was based on the norms and values of the colonizer)

A91E539039A247ADB80BD0D23FFD0BDE.description: Indicates the role of African populations in the colonial exploitation of territories (e.g. Africans were a source of cheap labour for the exploitation of agricultural and mineral resources)

A5604AAF77FC410EA3B558221E95EB18.description: Indicates sociopolitical consequences of the colonial division of Africa (e.g. since colonial borders did not always correspond to ethnic boundaries of African populations; the colonizing country could exacerbate ethnic tensions)

8B8D6A9E93EE44C58B59B6372F56D222.description: Explains the main outcome of the Berlin Conference: agreement between 13 countries that established the rules for the colonization of Africa

72B09509768F4EBFB7FE790FC13222F0.description: Explains some effects of the migration of millions of Europeans on the colonies’ original populations (e.g. by settling in the colonies, Europeans occupied the land of local populations and imposed their way of life on them)

31DBFFFA3DB24FA98BEEA3C436CB1B97.description: Explains how colonizers justified their dominance in Africa (e.g. Europeans were convinced that they were civilizing populations that were “inferior” to them)

399F294CEF7444FA98D42A23558B2FA8.description: Indicates factors that motivated imperialism (e.g. search for power and supremacy in Europe)

3C8EFDDD201E40EB9A0B251B603DD455.description: Indicates the types of products traded between colonizers and their colonies (e.g. the colonies exported resources and raw materials; the colonizers exported finished products)

BACB7A212C2045109507EBE5E39052C2.description: Indicates conditions required for a country to industrialize (e.g. access to capital, access to raw materials, access to a market for manufactured goods)

727322835EDF4B9BA10CC569985AE1EF.description: Locates on a time line facts related to imperialism and colonization

EA445FEFDE6E4E338F6B7FDD688A57F1.description: Locates on a map a few pre-colonial African societies or civilizations (e.g. Arab societies in North Africa; nomad societies of the Sahara; the Ghana and Mali empires)

EEE837B299E648BCB6D641F1D10D8554.description: Locates on a map the colonial empires of Britain and France at the beginning of the 20th century

35AB7817AA0C46D7BB1E67CAFC07E420.description: Expansion of the industrial world and the effects of European imperialism on African populations

4BF45E6ABA08499FA856DE2E41BA7C31.description: Names a few socioeconomic indicators that are used to illustrate global wealth disparity (e.g. life expectancy, gross domestic product per capita)

5147B167B316483683F442B1DFEB0ACA.description: Names areas that are outside national jurisdiction (e.g. Antarctica, areas of the ocean beyond exclusive economic zones)

A5DDAF1A64D047A1B0FECFB575A26F9D.description: Lists characteristics of a sovereign state (e.g. recognized international borders, member of the United Nations General Assembly)

2E69ADEE26594072A43783433306A7BA.description: Names individuals who have helped improve living conditions (e.g. Mother Teresa, Lucille Teasdale

E48CC7987270495187FBAD7BC79039E6.description: Names measures that can help improve living conditions in a society (e.g. education, labour standards)

C6B28B27C6E14B5CB7286A3C191FDF7C.description: Indicates some of the goals of organizations working to improve living conditions in society (e.g. to eradicate poverty, to eliminate child labour)

D929990C5955493798B1D9E42A3D38BC.description: Names organizations that work to improve living conditions (e.g. UNICEF, Oxfam)

42DE6CAE6B744DF89A94DD6DEBD2A094.description: Contribution of individuals and institutions to the improvement of living conditions in society today

849A81D1C0D940AC8C931079B289CFA8.description: Indicates actions taken by governments to deal with workers’ demands and demonstrations (e.g. repression, refusal to grant the right to organize, laissez-faire policy)

81EFE1810F634E14BE9699592E1F5F18.description: Lists principles shared by socialist and communist movements (e.g. common ownership of means of production, search for justice and social equality)

63A81FA48E2147A8938D0F25E7CECA94.description: Indicates advantages that unions provided for workers (e.g. power to negotiate with employers)

F49C7F2F8DF44CA5BECC503808EA6FAA.description: Indicates actions taken by workers to improve their social and economic situation (e.g. demands for the right to organize, demands for better working conditions, strikes)

AE3DA1328F65499DB48F9B1A85D50401.description: Describes some working conditions at the start of industrialization in Britain (e.g. long working hours, no rights or security, women and child labour)

C7B181E34D80413F8BE8394B7830082E.description: Indicates advantages of new means of transportation developed during the Industrial Revolution (e.g. steam locomotives and steam boats could maintain a steady speed and carry heavy loads, which facilitated the transportation of raw materials)

39B87C25AAA8451FA844B1E8353AFDC4.description: Explains some repercussions of profit seeking (e.g. to increase profits, the bourgeoisie tries to lower workers’ wages and raise the prices of goods sold)

127DDD67985846A9A1B0B8F34CD7E0C8.description: Indicates the source of income of the bourgeoisie: profit

B23EE9E682EC4F0A8314E40216C3CCE8.description: Names economic institutions associated with the development of capitalism (e.g. banks, stock exchange)

1E002E736B1C4230ABADAA84D62178FA.description: Lists some of the political principles of liberalism espoused by the bourgeoisie (e.g. free enterprise, few government restrictions, recognition of individual rights)

535C75499F874ACE8E7D983AFC4F4491.description: Lists characteristics of working-class neighbourhoods during the Industrial Revolution (e.g. proximity to factories; air pollution from coal burning; cramped, unsanitary housing)

3AC87A76CC7D46E790EF1F71C30BD205.description: Explains what differentiated the bourgeoisie from the working class, in terms of means of production (e.g. the bourgeoisie owned the means production; the workers owned labour power, which they sold for a wage or salary)

9100CB09A10F4FFFB3F7E5CB76B38C6E.description: Indicates factors that led to the formation of new social classes in industrializing societies (e.g. capital, employment)

C08AF75D53EE4CB7A8E682F00F3BC368.description: Indicates effects of industrialization on migration flows (e.g. rural exodus, urbanization)

5D3489F88AFE47BAB7AAC29FB64138F2.description: Names the sectors of production that were the first to industrialize: textile, metallurgy

429AA6A3D5584954920C5CAF3A28DA5C.description: Lists some characteristics of industrial production (e.g. mechanization of production, division of labour)

BC08E8811944468196307C7816B6F4EF.description: Indicates some of the causes of industrialization in 18th-century Britain (e.g. abundance of capital, technological innovation, increased agricultural production, available workforce, abundance of coal)

4148FE03675648809BA215E96FCAB1D3.description: Locates on a time line the industrial revolution and related facts (e.g. enclosure laws; Watt’s steam engine; the steam locomotive The Rocket)

AA767F6624564B6CB957DB55F01F0DB7.description: Locates on a map the first industrial territories and large cities of the 18th century (e.g. Liverpool, London, Manchester)

645A786F6BD449E4AA4656828874325E.description: Industrialization, an economic and social revolution, and its effects on British society

EAA24EC0178F498686B82536CF496C40.description: Indicates consequences of industrialization for society (e.g. urbanization, trade, consumer society)

D6783B11EC5C4C7EB145B200055CD1E6.description: Indicates factors that enable countries to industrialize (e.g. capital, workforce, resources)

99EC6749EA88402695FEE9A78137E525.description: Names countries that are industrializing (e.g. Brazil, China, India)

AD8D3D60D463487CB7A050B533593B66.description: Impact of industrialization on society today

CD2B247FD99C40C595F5CBFFBD6C3F14.description: Industrialization : an economic and social revolution

780D5450E4BC45E8A51BB851AF61CD5A.description: Indicates methods used by the international community to support the application of rights recognized by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (e.g. economic pressure, United Nations Peacekeepers or Blue Helmets)

1AB603A88394492084CB144B6981D626.description: Names international organizations dedicated to the protection of rights and freedoms (e.g. United Nations, International Criminal Court)

42F09DC2D6234EC6956A759DD134FEB0.description: Guarantees of rights and freedoms in society today

95AD6CEB67014BBA9CE84E135E7348E6.description: Names values promoted during the revolution

46C61F1094244DB087CDD9C326E49C9A.description: Indicates the mode of political organization on the eve of the revolution

A7AC7ADEA8E54DBBAEE2AECB311C786D.description: Indicates elements of the economic, political and social context on the eve of the revolution

D900887CCD114291AA4F2F530D1C3DF6.description: Indicates the three powers of the state defined in the Age of Enlightenment

3A0A76EB59864224B885666FA53A23A6.description: States principles of the philosophy of Enlightenment

EF7208F96AF04D2584DCFEF09AF1413E.description: Names Enlightenment philosophers who inspired revolutionary movements

D6B5DDA283184C1EB87F5C9ED90AC8A6.description: Locates on a time line the American or French revolution and related facts

E02539D65D7D412C960CFB60B7E06000.description: The American or French revolution and the role of revolutions in the conquest and recognition of fundamental rights

6FD036ED94D8419EAC0BD6587B30348C.description: States some of the human rights set forth in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of the United Nations (e.g. equality before the law; right to life, liberty and security)

3328CA4226B944F7A106D157F0B60E67.description: Names charters associated with the affirmation of human rights (e.g. Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Québec Charter of Human Rights and Freedoms, Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Convention on the Rights of the Child)

E86E95A8746A42E78B9AE6FA8720E7FB.description: Indicates the role of the World Trade Organization: it deals with the rules of trade between nations

BC94118620D84EC8B4A0539D716414D5.description: Names a country on each continent that has a European language as its official language (e.g. French in Senegal; English in India; Portuguese in Brazil)

17AA9F17FCE8477EB484FA9BA2162422.description: Economic and cultural relationships between societies today

4B48E7C129EA48029A464C33CEF8B864.description: Describes the consequences of European expansion in America for Native populations (e.g. certain nations were exterminated by war and disease; the culture and way of life of Native populations were profoundly changed)

C8C2F61D0AE74AED939AA328472DAFFE.description: Indicates resources or products imported by Europeans (e.g. gold, tobacco, fur, plants)

2BA792C4C72E44FC92C9D95FD3DAB5A9.description: Names Native populations living in America at the time of the first contact with the Europeans (e.g. the Incas, Aztecs, Iroquois, Algonquians)

2915613689A14FA3942ED5ECA241F542.description: Explains the consequences of the triangular trade for the colonies (e.g. it slowed the colonies’ economic development because their role was limited to exporting unprocessed resources)

834FE970828045CE93E9D9401F07945F.description: Indicates the main goods traded in the triangular trade: manufactured products, slaves, raw materials

65A464D1BFC34AD7BA851795524BDB79.description: Names the three legs of the triangular trade established by European colonial powers: Europe, Africa, American colonies

923FADF5529A4CC8B12F5E77A3EC64BA.description: Indicates a consequence of the Treaty of Tordesillas between Spain and Portugal in the 15th century (e.g. the line of demarcation established by the treaty gave Spain all of America except Brazil)

7426C84A7B5349DDAF5B40526DF891CA.description: Indicates the advantages of certain navigation instruments used by Europeans (e.g. the compass made it possible to find one’s way without visual reference points; the astrolabe was used to determine latitude)

5A0A952C9578462CB3A224700BD60152.description: Indicates some motivations for the great European explorations of the Renaissance (e.g. to find new trade routes to circumvent Constantinople; to look for spices, exotic products and precious metals)

209F1FDA66CF4055B92AF2E59F030B7C.description: Names the territories that were known to Europeans at the end of the 14th century: North Africa, the Near East and Europe

9DEBA607DD804716A909D0CFDADB51F6.description: Locates on a time line the great European explorations

5028CED831054C69983F9B44E4BC7D41.description: Locates on a map the colonial empires

8B63C75AEEA24E419AC348422B2009E2.description: Locates on a map the major European exploration routes

C58DC5EB89AD4C81B7A9389E22EB6143.description: European expansion in the world and the effects of an initial form of world economy on the societies of the American continent

9C08B4A3360A42A2BA47648D0FF1F486.description: Indicates some effects of the globalized economy (e.g. consumption of goods from many different countries, relocation of companies)

D4EEAA38876F44B0A4A6F75D17501ED3.description: Names major economic powers (e.g. The United States, China, Japan, the European Union, India, Brazil)

5FFC2A3F561349A2B3861AD133AB809E.description: States some of the principles of the Geneva Conventions (e.g. to protect civilian populations in armed conflicts; to outlaw military operations that do not distinguish between combatants and civilians and that cause serious lasting damage to the environment)

03B0BDCBC46F446694F56B946EB43150.description: Indicates some of the values of humanitarian organizations (e.g. Red Cross promotes tolerance; Doctors Without Borders, which promotes the right to humanitarian aid, provides urgent medical care to populations in need and to victims of war and natural disaster)

8086C24D0B524057954A98CA84331C1E.description: Indicates elements of continuity between the Renaissance and present-day society with respect to humanist thought (e.g. society values scientific and critical thought; society places importance on individual and collective responsibility)

DB926D3190C7493B97A43347ECDBA8CC.description: Humanist values in Western society today

E7EB8623C4FF4963A302109F8553F4AD.description: Lists characteristics shared by different Protestant churches (e.g. repudiation of the pope’s authority, importance of individual interpretation of the gospel)

05191D0DBED54205AB4438213ADAED12.description: Indicates actions taken by the Catholic Church to fight against the Reformation (e.g. refounding of the Inquisition, foundation of the Society of Jesus)

1999A07FB5CC4DAF869C0E068B9B2D9B.description: Names Protestant churches: Anglican, Calvinist, Lutheran

24E00CDB4DEE4CC690B6F4AEF84C3D85.description: Indicates factors that led individuals to challenge the authority of the Pope and the Catholic Church in the Renaissance (e.g. selling of indulgences, refusal of the Pope to annul the marriage of King Henry VIII of England)

8D35DA32236C4FCA97705A15F8E563DD.description: Indicates the impact of the printing press (e.g. decrease in the cost of books, spreading of knowledge and humanist ideas, publication of the Bible in many languages)

1BEDDDF71CFD4A8AA0724246426ADABC.description: Explains the reaction of the Church to new astronomical theories (e.g. the reaction was generally negative since heliocentrism seemed to trivialize the place of human beings in the universe; human beings were no longer the centre of divine creation)

FAD31969C4FF43E0801AD34E45D29F86.description: Indicates the impact of new scientific theories on certain fields in the Renaissance (e.g. in astronomy, the geocentric model was replaced by the heliocentric model; in medicine, dissections on cadavers made it possible to understand how the human body works)

17EC1D99D3564B848F7750C2F4B65F9F.description: Indicates elements that characterize Renaissance architecture (e.g. domes, triangular pediments, revival of architectural features from Antiquity)

22622D7E5AA14E8AB9DC4F78747B55A4.description: Indicates subjects often depicted by Renaissance painters and sculptors (e.g. human beings, nature)

588A814AFFE74788A7A28956801F055D.description: Indicates innovations that characterize Renaissance art (e.g. realism through use of perspective)

4C97EEFE2B1146F0A8742C5C6E57AC5A.description: Indicates elements of humanist thought about the world and the universe (e.g. reason, observation, experimentation)

916BEA81BDBA49F38882E1D618DF33B6.description: Names some of the great humanists of the Renaissance (e.g. Erasmus, Leonardo da Vinci, Montaigne)

7BCBBAEAC1944D948C5ABD320081324F.description: Indicates sources of the changes in thinking and the arts in the 15th and16th centuries (e.g. texts and works from Antiquity)

61D35DA49D51455DA91C14ADD3A8DF0A.description: Explains the concept of human beings in medieval Christian thought (e.g. God created human beings, God is the centre of the universe)

E3872E6072C1497E98BDBA282BA470DE.description: Locates on a time line the Renaissance and facts related to it

D618EE21FD8343EAAC034CDF93BFBE6C.description: Locates on a map the territories where the various Protestant churches prevailed

3BE365AD5CD044B6AB4DC7F648E0DBE7.description: Locates on a map the major European states and cities of the Renaissance

78E790D73931427FB7E3976D71BB5285.description: New vision of humanity and contribution of humanist ideas to the development of Western culture

9021AFD512E14078B0C64FDA1F3C6B65.description: Names scientific theories that may influence our concept of human beings and their place in the universe (e.g. theory of evolution, theory of relativity)

63686432A6304858B76FA32B3C8DD0C0.description: Indicates different concepts of human beings in society (e.g. environmentalism views human beings as one of many elements in the natural balance; liberalism views human beings as competing individuals guided by personal interests)

577A77147E654291A75AF47C422EF635.description: Concept of human beings in society and their place in the universe today

22E5D80DE8974007987BC51152D37FE3.description: Names public institutions that monitor the application of laws (e.g. ombudsperson, Office de la protection du consommateur, Office des personnes handicapées)

07C9C28BA0D849C6A6949D3496EE68B5.description: Indicates ways in which social groups can express their concerns (e.g. presentation of briefs to parliamentary commissions, petitions, letters of opinion in newspapers

8EC16AA9EB8342BFAA98C1C25182A60E.description: Indicates issues that could become subjects for debate between citizens and public institutions (e.g. labour standards, social housing, income tax, goods and services tax)

83765028BA8540FC8D833F2EB85F5D22.description: Indicates areas of public administration under the jurisdiction of one of the three levels of government (e.g. water supply and sewage disposal at the municipal level; education at the provincial level; currency and coinage at the federal level)

8BF0902E67114378BD9304F6A0894E19.description: Names associations responsible for defending collective interests (e.g. unions, professional corporations, employers’ organizations)

CE0BB003F91141789D2F5F8A7DE28046.description: Relationships between institutions and social groups today

D14247DCEC514ACA8B192D371A93299F.description: Explains the source of the merchant bourgeoisie’s wealth (e.g. the bourgeoisie made a profit from buying and selling products, which allowed them to accumulate capital)

08CC83F8BCF44095BEDA1D1F35E3F5DA.description: Indicates privileges of the bourgeoisie in feudal systems (e.g. charters granting exemption from certain feudal obligations, possibility of forming communes)

9BF298BF494A4043AE05261C3622BEE9.description: Names activities associated with the development of cities: crafts, trade

7F662D9D0B2043C38C8C825A81C28F6F.description: Indicates the role of fairs in the Middle Ages: places to sell goods obtained through large-scale European commerce

29A5B9A6578D4DDBA5C932DEE8AFA469.description: Names products traded in large-scale commerce (e.g. cloth, spices, metals)

A70B166F61024791A072941FCEA1BBEC.description: Names institutions that regulated large-scale commerce (e.g. Hanseatic League, guilds)

C15EF64563B342BF91D778CC0351CB74.description: Indicates factors that promoted the development of large-scale commerce in the Middle Ages (e.g. increased agricultural production, the iron wheel, the Crusades, the bill of exchange)

E8838430976A44249380AF96F3910FFB.description: Names craft guilds of the Middle Ages (e.g. butchers, masons, goldsmiths, weavers)

FCB7EEE017E743368D54C2B7C18A3550.description: Indicates the function of craft guilds (e.g. to control entry into trades, to protect members)

9640145C3C8C4BBA9A06BCCCBB3F5A27.description: Describes the organization of local craft trade (e.g. artisans made and sold the goods needed by the town’s inhabitants)

8A64186ACE93483DBDB5CDB8C62F6249.description: Names the institution responsible for the town’s administration: the commune

DED38CD3116B44AC84BFD6579921F813.description: Describes the organization of a medieval town (e.g. castle surrounded by walls, residential and commercial areas called “burgs” (or boroughs) where artisans and merchants were concentrated)
